occurrences.line_text: Was neuer wretched man in such a wofull cace.
The wretched man at his imperious speach,
That from thenceforth a wretched life they lad,
Can wretched Lady, quit from wofull state,
Most wretched men, whose dayes depend on thrids so vaine.
O   Why doe wretched men so much desire,
That all the wretched world recomforteth againe.
Who was to weet a wretched wearish elfe,
To whom thus aunswer'd was: Ah wretched wight
Death is to him, that wretched life doth lead,
A wofull wretched maid, of God and man forgot.
I rest his wretched thrall, the sad AEmylia.
And wast his wretched daies in wofull plight;
Arriuing there, he found this wretched man,
Whom when she saw in wretched weedes disguiz'd,
Or selfe disliked life doth thee thus wretched make?
Him wretched thrall vnto his dongeon brought,
Out of their wretched corses, and their liues depriue.
In wretched anguishe and incessant woe,
With which that wretched Greeke, that life forlore
And nam'd the riuer of his wretched fate;
Cares not what euils hap to wretched wight;
But let me waste in woe my wretched yeares,
She gan afresh thus to renew her wretched case.
In which his wretched loue lay day and night,
By wicked doome condemn'd, a wretched death to die.
So downe the cliffe the wretched Gyant tumbled;
The wretched mayd that earst desir'd to die,
But that same wretched man, ordaynd to die,
That euer in this wretched case ye were?
Through which she might his wretched life bereaue.
For yeelding so himselfe a wretched thrall,
In wretched bondage, wofully bestad.
But lies in wretched thraldome, weake and wan,
In which her wretched loue was captiue layd:
Hauing her selfe in wretched wize abiected,
Yet in that wretched semblant, she did sure
And wretched ruine of so high estate,
With piteous ruth of her so wretched plight,
And yeelding the last honour to her wretched corse.
For wretched woman, miserable wight,
And that so wretched one, as ye do see
And powred forth his wretched life in deadly dreare.
The which hast me, of all most wretched wight,
But by that Tyrant is in wretched thraldome bound.
Crying, and holding vp her wretched hands
To be the plague and scourge of wretched men:
What cruell hand thy wretched thraldome wrought,
The wretched man, that all this while did dwell
Is now him selfe in much more wretched plight;
That was a straunger to her wretched case;
And wretched life forlorne for vengement of his theft.
And wretched sorrowes, which haue often hapt?
By gentle vsage of that wretched Dame.
Now wringing both his wretched hands in one,
Would streight dislodge the wretched wearie life.
Or else remained in most wretched state,
And wretched end, which still attendeth on her.
That with the ruth of her so wretched case,
And onely suffred him this wretched life to liue.
Lay in the lap of death, rewing his wretched bale.
The more would wretched louers her adore.
That slaine he was, or made a wretched thrall,
Fell into wretched woes, which she repented late.
These two, vnworthy of your wretched bands;
Nor heauens, nor men can me most wretched mayd
And now all weetlesse of the wretched stormes,
Her wretched life, shut vp in deadly shade,
Wrapped in wretched cares and hearts vnrest,
But Pastorella, wofull wretched Elfe,
So leaue we her in wretched thraldome bound,
The sad remembrance of her wretched plight.
Yet could not remedie her wretched case;
Would for the wretched infants helpe prouyde,
Wretchedly wearing out his youthly yeares,
That many erra[n]t knights hath brought to wretchednesse.
Then beautie brought t'vnworthy wretchednesse
Where they should liue in woe, & die in wretchednesse.
That death him did awaite in dayly wretchednesse.
And made that caitiues thral, the thral of wretchednesse.
No wretchednesse is like to sinfull vellenage.
Did heape on her new waues of weary wretchednesse.
Must not here thinke to liue: for life is wretchednesse.
And captiue with her led to wretchednesse and wo.
Come home to her in piteous wretchednesse,
Which gaue beginning to her woe and wretchednesse.
Couer'd with cold, and wrapt in wretchednesse,
The witnesse of his wretchednesse, in place,
Liker to heauen, then mortall wretchednesse.
The wretchedst Dame, that liue this day on ground;
On which had many wretches hanged beene,
Death is for wretches borne vnder vnhappie starre.
Vile caytiue wretches, ragged, rude, deformd,
For spoyle of wretches, whose vnhappie cace,
And wreckes of many wretches, which did weepe,
Of many wretches set his triumphes hye,
Vouchsafe with mild regard a wretches cace to heare.
Haue care of right, or ruth of wretches wrong,
Or else by wracke, that wretches hath distrest,
Which when I wretch,---Not one word more she sayd
Tho wrapping vp her wrethed sterne arownd,
A loathly, wrinckled hag, ill fauoured, old,
And eke her face ill fauourd, full of wrinckles old.
So backward still was turnd his wrincled face,
Then of the grieuous smart, which him did wring,
To spin, to card, to sew, to wash, to wring;
Long did he wrest and wring it to and fro,
The warie foule his bill doth backward wring;
Wringing her hands in wemens pitteous wise,
Wringing her hands, and making piteous mone;
Now wringing both his wretched hands in one,
Wringing her hands, and ruefully loud crying?
And next her wrinkled skin rough sackcloth wore,
In whose great shield was writ with letters gay
Was writ Sans ioy, they new arriued find:
Was writ with golden letters rich and braue;
Wherein darke things were writ, hard to be vnderstood.
Dwelt fortie dayes vpon; where writ in stone
Then to his hands that writ he did betake,
And round about the wreath this word was writ,
Whereon the Faery Queenes pourtract was writ,
With sundry colours, in the which were writ
Therein was writ, how often thundring Ioue
All which in that faire arras was most liuely writ.
But what so were therein or writ or ment,
How ouer that same dore was likewise writ,
Another yron dore, on which was writ,
And oftentimes doe wish it neuer had bene writ.
His word, which on his ragged shield was writ,
My chaster Muse for shame doth blush to write;
And write the battels of his great godhed:
It falles me here to write of Chastity,
Be thou faire Britomart, whose prayse I write,
Whiles of a wanton Lady I do write,
Or therein write to let his loue be showne;
Rowme in their writs; yet the same writing small
And writing strange characters in the ground,
Rowme in their writs; yet the same writing small
O cursed Eld the cankerworme of writs,
More then my former writs, all were they clearest
From leprous mouth on all, that euer writt:
Deepe written in my heart with yron pen,
Are written sure, and haue their certaine date.
As it in bookes hath written bene of old.
In which there written was with cyphers old,
And thinke of that faire visage, written in her hart.
And vnderneath his feet was written thus,
Ouer the dore thus written she did spye
Wherein it written was, and how himselfe he blist:
And in the marble stone was written this,
There written was the purport of his sin,
BON FONT: but bon that once had written bin,
Her wrizled skin as rough, as maple rind,
To haue bene wroght by that false sorceresse.
Vpon the old, him stirring to be wroke
Thereof deuising shortly to be wroke,
Whilest he on him was greedy to be wroke,
Into his hart, and had so sternely wroke
Both greedie fiers on other to be wroken.
And said; Be not vpon thy balance wroken:
Iustice that day of wrong her selfe had wroken,
For any brybes, or threates of any to be wroken.
So long as these two armes were able to be wroken.
That I must rue his vndeserued wrong:
And simple truth subdue auenging wrong?
And all that he by right or wrong could find,
But did vsurpe with wrong and tyrannie
And right and wrong ylike in equall ballaunce waide.
So th'one for wrong, the other striues for right:
So th'one for wrong, the other striues for right,
Thy guilty wrong, or else thee guilty yield.
Or else his wrong with greater puissance maintaine.
A gentle Ladie, or her wrong through might:
By tortious wrong, or whom bereau'd of right.
But still prouokt her sonne to wreake her wrong;
His am I Atin, his in wrong and right,
And Atin aie him pricks with spurs of shame & wrong.
Outrageous wrong, and hellish couetize,
Thou canst preserue from wrong and robbery?
Them to efforce by violence or wrong;
And all by wrong wayes for themselues prepard.
On this vile bodie from to wreake my wrong,
And to recouer right for such, as wrong did grieue.
So vnto wrong to yield my wrested right:
To weene your wrong by force to iustifie:
Then I auow to thee, by wrong or right
O do thy cruell wrath and spightfull wrong
To reskew her from shame, and to reuenge her wrong.
And oft him threatned death for his outrageous wrong.
Nor Aeolus sharp blast could worke them any wrong.
Who to auenge the implacable wrong,
Redresse the wrong of miserable wight,
The golden Apple, cause of all their wrong,
Or answere for thy wrong, as shall fall out in fight.
Braue Knights and Ladies, certes ye doe wrong
That first I may that wrong to him requite:
But if the heauens helpe to redresse her wrong,
That at the last of all his woe and wrong
Hath done this wrong, to wreake on worthlesse wight
The which that tyrant gathered had by wrong
To rip vp wrong, that battell once hath tried;
And yet (quoth she) a greater wrong remaines:
And wall'd by nature gainst inuaders wrong,
Gainst all that would it faine to force or wrong.
Now well away, that I haue doen such wrong,
Haue care of right, or ruth of wretches wrong,
Daughter me seemes of double wrong ye plaine,
Right now is wrong, and wrong that was is right,
Right now is wrong, and wrong that was is right,
And wrong repressed, and establisht right,
There she him taught to weigh both right and wrong
In all the skill of deeming wrong and right,
And wrong redresse in such as wend awry.
And makes them subiect to his mighty wrong;
In stead of right me seemes great wrong dost shew,
Were it not good that wrong were then surceast,
What wrong then is it, if that when they die,
The right or wrong, the false or else the trew?
But he could iustly weigh the wrong or right.
And counterpeise the same with so much wrong.
To fill the other scale with so much wrong.
For they doe nought but right or wrong betoken;
For they with wrong or falshood will not fare;
And for to maister wrong and puissant pride,
And makes wrong doers iustice to deride,
But seeming to haue suffred mickle wrong,
Of a late wrong vppon a mortall foe;
Vpon your selues anothers wrong to wreake?
Ne him sufficeth all the wrong and ill,
And on his Lady, th'author of that wrong,
Iustice that day of wrong her selfe had wroken,
Purchast through lawlesse powre and tortious wrong
As Wrong, when it hath arm'd it selfe with might?
That right long time is ouerborne of wrong,
Who all that wrong vnto that wofull Dame
Can keepe from outrage, and from doing wrong,
And right and wrong most cruelly confound:
With which he wont to fight, to iustifie his wrong.
That thorough some more mighty enemies wrong,
And it hath long mayntaind with mighty wrong:
For recompence of all their former wrong:
May witnesse well, did offer first to wrong,
For armed knight a wight vnarm'd to wrong.
To wreake on me the guilt of his owne wrong.
To wrong the weaker, oft falles in his owne assault.
Should weet of me, nor worke me any wrong.
And lastly in approuance of thy wrong,
For greater force there needs to maintaine wrong, then right.
Sith he likewise did wrong by him sustaine,
Detaynd, yet Fortune not with all this wrong
Or vnto louely Lady doing wrong:
And all such persons, as he earst did wrong,
Who wrongd by Carle by Proteus sau'd,
I am the wrong'd, whom ye did enterprise
That all vnweeting haue you wrong'd thus sore,
As he her wronged innocence did weet.
As a chast Virgin, that wronged beene:
Gainst one that hath both wronged you, and vs:
In the behalfe of wronged weake did fight:
And doubting to be wronged, or beguyled,
Then two speares length; So mischiefe ouermatcht the wronger.
So mak'st thou kings, & gaynest wrongfull gouernement.
The wrongfull outrage of vnrighteous men,
In open turney, and by wrongfull fight
But she that wrongfull challenge soone assoyled,
With wrongfull powre oppressing others of their kind.
That Damzell, whom he held as wrongfull prisonere.
To which they had no right, nor any wrongfull state.
Whether withheld from me by wrongfull might,
A wrongfull quarrell to maintaine by fight;
The which hath doen to thee this wrongfull deed,
And for reuengement of those wrongfull smarts,
Gainst which me seemes this war ye wrongfully haue wielded.
Not wronging any other by my will,
Anothers wrongs to wreake vpon thy selfe:
And for these wrongs shall treble penaunce pay
All wrongs haue mends, but no amends of shame.
To plaine of wrongs, which had committed bin
Of his late wrongs, in which she oft him blamed
It seemes, iust wrongs to vengeance doe prouoke,
But casting wrongs and all reuenge behind,
And all thy wrongs will wipe out of my souenaunce.
But wreake your wrongs wrought to this knight alone,
On his sonne Edwin all those wrongs shall wreake;
For which he others wrongs, and wreckes himselfe;
The open wrongs, thou doest me day by day;
And dayly he his wrongs encreaseth more,
Which she with wrongs hath heaped vp so hy,
But all the wrongs that he therein could lay,
Yet all the wrongs could not a litle right downe lay.
And put two wrongs together to be tride,
Right in their wrongs, are rul'd by righteous lore
Al those great wrongs, the which that mayd complained
As by sad Belge seemes, whose wrongs though long
And triumphes of PhlegrÃ¦an Ioue he wrote,
This gentle Damzell, whom I wrote vpon,
Who thereat wondrous wroth, the sleeping spark
Yet did she thinke her pearelesse wroth to pas
The goddesse wroth gan fowly her disgrace,
How may it be, (said then the knight halfe wroth,)
Which when Sir Guyon saw, all were he wroth,
He wexed wondrous wroth, and said, Vile knight,
Exceeding wroth was Guyon at that blow,
That hasty wroth, and heedlesse hazardrie,
Then Mammon wexing wroth, And why then, said,
Foolish old man, said then the Pagan wroth,
Wroth was the Prince, and sory yet withall,
And ransackt Greece well tryde, whe[n] they were wroth;
Whe[n] the wroth Western wind does reaue their locks;
Whereat Excesse exceedingly was wroth,
Where at Cadwallin wroth, shall forth issew,
And woxe halfe wroth against her damzels slacke,
Her mildly answer'd; Beldame be not wroth
To wexe exceeding wroth, and him ared
Whereat he gan to wex exceeding wroth,
That, were it not for shame,---So turned from him wroth.
Exceeding wroth therewith the virgin grew,
And boastfull chalenge, wexed inlie wroth,
Ne be ye wroth Sir Scudamour therefore,
Exceeding wroth thereat was Blandamour,
But Triamond halfe wroth to see him staid,
Whereat full inly wroth was Triamond,
Thereat exceeding wroth was Satyran;
And wroth with Satyran was Blandamour;
And wroth with Blandamour was Eriuan;
Through iealous passion weeping inly wroth,
Eurypulus, that calmes the waters wroth;
To whom he aunswerd wroth, Loe there thy hire;
Which when the Pagan saw, he wexed wroth,
Thou foolishe Elfe (said then the Gyant wroth)
Wroth wext he then, and sayd, that words were light,
Wherewith though wondrous wroth, and inly burning,
But she thereat was wroth, that for despight
Wroth with the Gods, which to perpetuall paine
Wherewith full wroth, he fiercely gan assay,
Wherewith he wroth, and full of proud disdaine,
Sir Calepine her thanckt, yet inly wroth
Then Calepine, how euer inly wroth,
Which when as Cupid heard, he wexed wroth,
The villaine, wroth for greeting him so sore,
The knight yet wrothfull for his late disgrace,
That they at last their wrothfull hands let fall,
Where being layd, the wrothfull Britonesse
Eftsoones they gan their wrothfull hands to hold,
But where then is (quoth he halfe wrothfully)
And mightie causes wrought in heauen aboue,
Through that late vision, which th'Enchaunter wrought,
A wondrous way it for this Lady wrought,
As when that diuelish yron Engin wrought
Both shield, and sword, and armour all he wrought
Which loue and fortune in her heart had wrought,
Had wrought that horror strange, and dar'd his dreaded powre.
For wondrous anguish in his hart it wrought,
Least so great good, as he for her had wrought,
The percing steele there wrought a wound full wyde,
Vnwares me wrought vnto her wicked will,
And liues he yet (said he) that wrought this act,
And read, who hath ye wrought this shamefull plight.
That wrought the shamefull fact, which I did shew;
A knight had wrought against a Ladie gent;
His be the praise, that this atchieu'ment wrought,
Such is this well, wrought by occasion straunge,
Had wrought, and many whelmd in deadly paine,
T'auenge his Pare[n]ts death on them, that had it wrought.
So fortune wrought, as vnder greene woods syde
At last such grace I found, and meanes I wrought,
Confest, how Philemon her wrought to chaunge her weede.
To wreake my wrath on him, that first it wrought.
To kindle his quencht fire, and thousand causes wrought.
And weetlesse eke of lately wrought despight,
But wrought by art and counterfetted shew,
Sith wrathfull hand wrought not her owne desire?
That hath to Paynim knights wrought great distresse,
That it in flames of Aetna wrought apart,
Through all those foldes the steelehead passage wrought
Braunched with gold & pearle, most richly wrought,
Was trimly wouen, and in tresses wrought,
Of hewen stone the porch was fairely wrought,
In which was nothing pourtrahed, nor wrought,
Not wrought, nor pourtrahed, but easie to be thought.
Ascending by ten steps of Alablaster wrought.
Atchieuement wrought with perill and with paine,
And eke the gate was wrought of substaunce light,
The art, which all that wrought, appeared in no place.
Her garments all were wrought of beaten gold,
But wreake your wrongs wrought to this knight alone,
Which in that cloth was wrought, as if it liuely grew.
What euer foe had wrought, or frend had faynd,
And by what meanes his loue might best be wrought:
To weet the mighty Ollyphant, that wrought
That her out of astonishment he wrought,
Besides the huge massacres, which he wrought
Which he had wrought to many others moe.
Wrought with wilde Antickes, which their follies playd,
To cruell loue, and wrought their owne decayes:
Which wrought it, could the same recure againe.
Which that rich Romane of white marble wrought,
And much the more, by that he lately wrought,
How she might ouerthrow the things that Concord wrought.
That by themselues vnto themselues is wrought,
Amongst her louers, and great quarrels wrought,
Which doughty Triamond had wrought that day,
With which they wrought such wondrous maruels there,
And wrought in Lemno with vnquenched fire:
Which secret fate hath in this Ladie wrought,
So well he woo'd her, and so well he wrought her,
Or his exchange, or freedome might be wrought.
That of a fishes shell was wrought with rare delight.
That Florimell it was, which wrought his paine,
Read therefore who it is, which this hath wrought,
Who was it then (sayd Artegall) that wrought?
Nor powr of charms, which she against him wrought,
But this the sword, which wrought those cruell stounds,
But th'emptie girdle, which about her wast was wrought.
And to haue wrought vnwares some villanous assay.
But who can scape, what his owne fate hath wrought?
And vnto them wrought all the villany,
But wrought by Clarins wile.
Wouen vppon with siluer, subtly wrought,
So cunningly she wrought her crafts assay,
Those warlike weedes, till she reuenge had wrought
So well as could with cunning hand be wrought,
And royall gifts of gold and siluer wrought,
Could ought on earth so wondrous change haue wrought,
That false Duessa, which had wrought great care,
What cruell hand thy wretched thraldome wrought,
Against both which that knight wrought knightlesse shame.
Which had this outrage wrought with wicked hand.
Which to your selfe he wrought, & to your loued knight.
Because of one, that wrought him fowle despight.
Had not a wondrous chaunce his reskue wrought,
The iuyce whereof into his wound he wrought,
And with her husband vnder hand so wrought,
And euer more and more her owne affliction wrought.
It neuer rests, till it haue wrought his finall bane.
Wrought to Sir Calidore so foule despight;
The wrathfull Prince, & wrought her husbands peace,
And in the Princes gardin daily wrought:
Both of his speach that wrought him great content,
Good will and fauour. So it surely wrought
So well he wood her, and so well he wrought her,
And wrought so well with labour and long paine,
Hath wrought this wicked deed: doe feare away, and tell.
Yet Calidore so well him wrought with meed,
Or secret guifts so with his keepers wrought,
Whom to recomfort, all the meanes he wrought,
He wrought, that thence all goodnesse he bereft,
Thenceforth more mischiefe and more scath he wrought
Declare at once; and hath he lost or wun?
In trauell to and froe: a little wyde
Long she thus traueiled through deserts wyde,
Himselfe too nigh at hand, but turned wyde
Seeing the gored woundes to gape so wyde,
Discouered had the world to heauen wyde,
Who had more ioy to raunge the forrest wyde,
And shut vp heauens windowes shyning wyde:
And tassels gay. Wyde wonders ouer all
She him obayd, and turnd a little wyde.
Then with his wauing wings displayed wyde,
The percing steele there wrought a wound full wyde,
He bad to open wyde his brazen gate,
At proud Cymochles, whiles his shield was wyde,
Wyde was the wound, and a large lukewarme flood,
At length they came into a forrest wyde,
Mantled with greene, it selfe did spredden wyde,
To hunt the saluage beast in forrest wyde,
Whose vertues through the wyde world soone were solemniz'd.
My feeble brest of late, and launched this wound wyde.
Who long time wandred through the forrest wyde,
Yet sought the saluage woods and forrests wyde,
But to the wound his weake hart opened wyde;
Whiles the proud Bird ruffing his fethers wyde,
That his swift charet might haue passage wyde,
And euery wood, and euery valley wyde
And the wyde wound, which lately did dispart
Euen immortall praise, and glory wyde,
Would to his hope a windowe open wyde,
The wicked shaft guyded through th'ayrie wyde,
Then caused he the gates be opened wyde,
Als at his backe a great wyde net he bore,
Stood open wyde to all men day and night;
Went vp the hall, that was a large wyde roome,
That her brode spreading wings did wyde vnfold;
Are so exceeding spacious and wyde,
With many wounds full perilous and wyde,
Gaping full wyde, did thinke without remorse
Went forth streightway into the forrest wyde,
He found the gate wyde ope, and in he rode,
Witnesse the wounds, and this wyde bloudie lake,
Which was, that through this worlds wyde wildernes
Like two great Beacons, glared bright and wyde,
His brode black wings had through the heauens wyde
Like as a ship, that through the Ocean wyde
And wyder made the wound of th'hidden dart.
The wyld woodgods arriued in the place,
A Satyres sonne yborne in forrest wyld,
And eke wyld roring Buls he would him make
Wyld beasts in yron yokes he would compell;
Whom he hath left in yonder forrest wyld:
Did spend her dayes, and lov'd in forests wyld to space.
